data.title: What's the meaning of "Down Under"??
data.meta_description: I like Men at Work but have never really understood the lyrics to "Down Under"??  What the heck does it mean?  Or does it mean nothing, really....?
data.text:
Down Under

Traveling in a fried-out combie

On a hippie trail, head full of zombie

I met a strange lady, she made me nervous

She took me in and gave me breakfast

And she said,

"Do you come from a land down under?

Where women glow and men plunder?

Can't you hear, can't you hear the thunder?

You better run, you better take cover."

Buying bread from a man in Brussels

He was six foot four and full of muscles

I said, "Do you speak-a my language?"

He just smiled and gave me a vegemite sandwich

And he said,

"I come from a land down under

Where beer does flow and men chunder

Can't you hear, can't you hear the thunder?

You better run, you better take cover."

Lying in a den in Bombay

With a slack jaw, and not much to say

I said to the man, "Are you trying to tempt me

Because I come from the land of plenty?"

And he said,

"Oh! Do you come from a land down under? (oh yeah yeah)

Where women glow and men plunder?

Can't you hear, can't you hear the thunder?

You better run, you better take cover."

As has been said this is a paean to Oz (Australia) written from the perspective of an expatriate. Words you may not be familiar with are 'combie' - a combination of vehicle and home, usually an old VW Caravanette; 'vegemite' - the Oz version of Marmite (a yeast extract spread); 'chunder' - chuck, technicolour yawn, liquid laugh, hurl, to play the whale, to cry Ruth, the big spit, laugh at the ground, to yodel, to expel a jet of partially digested nutrient.

Firstly, a minor correction. The 'Combie' isn't 'Combie' but 'Kombi' and is short for Kombinationskraftwagen, which is the type of Volkwagen camper van that many Australians would buy on the cheap and drive across the Hippie Trail.

Other factets that people may be interested in:

The Hippie Trail referred to was the well trodden route that ran from Northern Europe, through Istanbul, Tehran, Kabul, and down to Delhi, Kathmandu, and, ultimately on to Bangkok.

Where women glow supposedly refers to the sweat that Australian women suffer from due to the heat in Australia.

Men plundering is a reference to men in Australia plundering the natural resources of the country.

The term chunder does indeed mean throw-up (puke, etc), but it's also referring to the Australian male tendency to drink to excess, especially when abroad. The song was really a dig at Australians abroad who, in the writer's view, often misbehaved as they wandered the planet, thinking that everyone adored them, when in fact they were often being ridiculous.

The song was inspired by a Barry Humphries character called Barry McKenzie, nephew to another of Humphries' characters Dame Edna Everage. In that sense it is meant to be satirical, I believe.
